greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is the smallest number m greater than 1 such that phi(m) = d(m)^n, where d(m) is number of positive divisors of m; if there is no such m, a(n)=1.
comment: For n=0,1,2,3, and 4, a(2^n) = A000215(n), the n-th Fermat prime.
Conjecture: A000005(a(n)) <= 12 for all n. [_Max Alekseyev_, May 07 2010]
This conjecture holds throughout the first 102 terms. - _David A. Corneth_, Jun 14 2020
link: David A. Corneth, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..100
Max Alekseyev, PARI scripts for various problems (see invphitau there).
example: a(10) = 1114129 because phi(1114129) = d(1114129)^10 and 1114129 is the smallest number m greater than 1 that phi(m) = 1048576 = 4^10 = d(m)^10.
program: (PARI) a(n)=res = oo; for(i=2, oo, if(i^n > res, return(res)); c=invphitau(i^n,i); if(#c>0, res=c[1])) \\ for invphitau, see Alekseyev link \\ _David A. Corneth_, Jun 14 2020
results.author: _Farideh Firoozbakht_, Jun 06 2005
ext: Terms a(11) onward from _Max Alekseyev_, May 07 2010
Terms a(20)-a(23), offset corrected by _David A. Corneth_, Jun 14 2020
